flixel.util.FlxCollision

type
class
FlxCollision

Static Variables

CAMERA_WALL_INSIDE(inline,null) : Int

CAMERA_WALL_OUTSIDE(inline,null) : Int

debug : flash.display.BitmapData

Static Methods

createCameraWall(Camera : flixel.FlxCamera, Placement : Int, Thickness : Int, ?AdjustWorldBounds : Bool) : flixel.group.FlxGroup

parameters
Camera The FlxCamera to use for the wall bounds (can be FlxG.camera for the current one)
Placement CAMERA_WALL_OUTSIDE or CAMERA_WALL_INSIDE
Thickness The thickness of the wall in pixels
AdjustWorldBounds Adjust the FlxG.worldBounds based on the wall (true) or leave alone (false)
returns
FlxGroup The 4 FlxTileblocks that are created are placed into this FlxGroup which should be added to your State
Creates a "wall" around the given camera which can be used for FlxSprite collision

pixelPerfectCheck(Contact : flixel.FlxSprite, Target : flixel.FlxSprite, ?AlphaTolerance : Int, ?Camera : flixel.FlxCamera) : Bool

parameters
Contact The first FlxSprite to test against
Target The second FlxSprite to test again, sprite order is irrelevant
AlphaTolerance The tolerance value above which alpha pixels are included. Default to 255 (must be fully opaque for collision).
Camera If the collision is taking place in a camera other than FlxG.camera (the default/current) then pass it here
returns
Boolean True if the sprites collide, false if not
A Pixel Perfect Collision check between two FlxSprites. It will do a bounds check first, and if that passes it will run a pixel perfect match on the intersecting area. Works with rotated and animated sprites. It's extremly slow on cpp targets, so I don't recommend you to use it on them. Not working on neko target and awfully slows app down

pixelPerfectPointCheck(PointX : Int, PointY : Int, Target : flixel.FlxSprite, ?AlphaTolerance : Int) : Bool

parameters
PointX The x coordinate of the point given in local space (relative to the FlxSprite, not game world coordinates)
PointY The y coordinate of the point given in local space (relative to the FlxSprite, not game world coordinates)
Target The FlxSprite to check the point against
AlphaTolerance The alpha tolerance level above which pixels are counted as colliding. Default to 255 (must be fully transparent for collision)
returns
Boolean True if the x/y point collides with the FlxSprite, false if not
A Pixel Perfect Collision check between a given x/y coordinate and an FlxSprite
